Welcome to cardlib’s documentation!¶

class cardlib.AceCard(suit: cardlib.Suit, first=False)¶

Bases: cardlib.PlayingCard

This class is representing the Ace cards in the Poker game. AceCard is a child of PlayingCard abstract class.

get_value()¶

Returns the value of a AceCard.

Returns

value of a ace card which is 14 by default.

Return type

int

class cardlib.Hand(cards=None)¶

Bases: object

Sets a class of hand. The card attribute is a list of PlayingCard objects.

add_card(new_card)¶

Adds the “new_card” to the hand.

Parameters

new_card (a PlayingCard object) – A PlayingCard object to be added to Hand.

best_poker_hand(cards=None)¶

Calculates the best poker hand of the hand, and the added cards

Parameters

cards (PlayinCard) – List of playing cards in addition to the hand cards.

Returns

PokerHand-class with best poker hand type and best cards.

Return type

Hand

drop_cards(index=None)¶

Drops the cards presented by index.

Parameters

index (list) – A list (or integer) of indices, with first position given as 0.

Returns

Card(s) given by index

Return type

PlayinCard

show_hand()¶

Presents the cards in the hand.

sort()¶

Sorts the cards by value and returns a sorted cards in a hand.

sort_cards()¶

Sorts the cards by value

sort_cards_by_suit()¶

Sorts the cards by both value and suit, (Clubs, Diamonds, Hearts and Spades)

class cardlib.PlayingCard(suit: cardlib.Suit)¶

Bases: object

Abstract class for playing cards for the deck. Ranked as NumberedCard: 2-10, JackCard: 11, QueenCard: 12, KingCard: 13 and AceCard: 14 Suits are given as Suit.Spades, Suit.Hearts, Suit.Diamonds or Suit.Clubs according the Suit class.

This abstract class enforces its child classes to overload two operators and one method: 1. Operator < 2. Operator == 3. Method get_value()

abstract get_value()¶

Returns the value of a PlayingCard object which is an int in range [2,14]. :return:

class cardlib.PokerHand(cards)¶

Bases: object

Calculates the best poker hand of the given cards.

Example: >>> h1 = Hand([NumberedCard(2,Suit.Hearts),

NumberedCard(2,Suit.Spades), NumberedCard(5,Suit.Spades), NumberedCard(5,Suit.Hearts), NumberedCard(10,Suit.Clubs)])

>>> ph1 = PokerHand(h1.cards)
>>> ph1.hand_type
<PokerHandType.TWO_PAIR: 3>
class cardlib.PokerHandType(value)¶

Bases: enum.IntEnum

This is an enumerate class for the different poker hand type with their corresponding rank/value. Highest value i.e. STRAIGHT_FLUSH with value 9 is the best.

This class is representing the Queen cards in the Poker game. QueenCard is a child of PlayingCard abstract class.

class cardlib.StandardDeck¶

Bases: object

Creates a standard deck of 52 playing cards.

draw()¶

Draws (removes) the top (last) card from the card-list

Returns

A playing card.

Return type

PlayingCard

new_deck()¶

Creates a new list of 52 playing cards in StandardDeck.cards

shuffle()¶

Reorders the list of cards into a random order.

class cardlib.Suit(value)¶

Bases: enum.Enum

This is an enumerated class for four different playing card suits. Suits are not ranked and any given numbers are for sorting purposes only. Here, the unicode characters to symbolise the playing cards have been used.

Parameters

  • Spades (enum 'Suit') – Representing spades.

  • Hearts (enum 'Suit') – Representing hearts.

  • Diamonds (enum 'Suit') – Representing diamonds.

  • Clubs (enum 'Suit') – Representing clubs.
